semantic_identifier: 6912647 - Quantacrest Nanotech - buy - Discussion with Wendy Warren

hierarchy.meeting_title: 6912647 - Quantacrest Nanotech - buy - Discussion with Wendy Warren

sections.text: Camila Vega: Hi Wendy—good to see you again. Since this is our third call, I wanted to use the time to align on what it would take to get Sales_Accelerator approved and kicked off this month. Does that still match what you’re aiming for at Quantacrest Nanotech?
Wendy Warren: Hi Camila. I’m open to it, but I’ll be upfront—there are a couple of concerns we need to resolve before we can commit.

Camila Vega: Totally fair. Let’s make it practical. Last time you mentioned two pain points: your weekly forecast swings late in the quarter, and managers spend too much time chasing pipeline hygiene. If we solve those with minimal disruption to Salesforce, would you feel comfortable moving forward?
Wendy Warren: If it truly doesn’t create extra work for reps, then maybe. But we’ve been burned by “layers” that become another place to log in and another dashboard nobody uses.

Camila Vega: That’s exactly the adoption trap we try to avoid. Let me focus on two things only: our forecasting and the pipeline hygiene workflow—both designed to run off your existing CRM data and activity signals. On forecasting, Sales_Accelerator doesn’t just mirror Salesforce stages; it combines stage data with activity—emails, calls, meetings—plus cycle-time benchmarks and your historical win rates. And it’s explainable: it shows the drivers, like stage age, last touch, whether a next meeting is scheduled, and optionally a fit tier if you’re using Customer_Analyzer.

Wendy Warren: The explainable part is appealing. Our leadership hates “black box” forecasts. But what’s the actual day-to-day change for reps? Because they already complain about Salesforce being heavy.

Camila Vega: For reps, the value is less data entry, not more. The pipeline hygiene use case is the simplest example: managers get weekly alerts for missing next steps, stale opps, and single-threaded deals. Reps don’t have to hunt through reports—they get an ordered top-10 task queue of fixes that will most improve forecast health: “schedule next meeting,” “update close date,” “identify a second contact,” that kind of thing.
Wendy Warren: That sounds good on paper, but that queue lives where? If it’s in your tool, that’s the problem. They live in Salesforce and Slack. Anything else becomes a ghost town.

Camila Vega: Understood. Our standard deployment is: the insights are visible in our layer, but the actions push back into Salesforce—so updating next steps, dates, contact roles, that’s all done in Salesforce. And we can notify in Slack or email for the alerts so they’re not dependent on logging in.
Wendy Warren: But you still just said “visible in our layer.” That’s exactly the context switching. If the rep has to open something else to understand why an opp is flagged, adoption drops.

Camila Vega: Let me ask a clarifying question: is it a hard requirement that the full experience be inside Salesforce—like embedded views—or is it acceptable if the rep gets a Slack alert and can click through only when needed?

Wendy Warren: For our culture, it’s basically a hard requirement. We’ve rolled out tools before where “only managers use it,” and then it dies. If this becomes another manager-only dashboard, we won’t buy it.

Camila Vega: That’s helpful. We do have customers who run it manager-first—weekly pipeline review, forecast calls, hygiene automation—then expand to reps once they see it helps. Could that pattern work at Quantacrest? Start with managers to stabilize the forecast, prove the impact, then roll out to reps?

Wendy Warren: Possibly, but our goal isn’t just forecasting accuracy. We’re trying to reduce rep admin time. If reps don’t engage, we’re not solving the underlying problem. Also, our RevOps team is small. They won’t support a big change-management effort.

Camila Vega: Got it. On RevOps effort: implementation is light because we’re not replacing Salesforce—we sit on top, ingest your opportunity and activity data, then generate the forecast views—commit, best-case, pipeline—plus diagnostics like stage conversion and slippage. We also do scenario planning, like “if we add 20 SQLs in Tier-1 ICP, what happens,” but you can ignore that if you want. The most immediate value is those explainable drivers: you can finally see which deals are drifting because there’s no next meeting, or because the stage age is off relative to your benchmarks.
Wendy Warren: We can already see stage age in Salesforce, though. It’s not elegant, but it exists. The question is: why add another product?

Camila Vega: Because stage age alone doesn’t tell you what’s likely to close or what to do next. Sales_Accelerator connects the dots between stage, actual activity signals, and your historical patterns. And it doesn’t just report—this is the execution layer part—it recommends next actions. The forecast becomes something you can improve during the month, not just defend at the end.
Wendy Warren: I hear you. But I’m still stuck on the “where.” Our reps won’t click into another tool just to see recommendations. Even Slack alerts can become noise.

Camila Vega: If Salesforce-native is the bar, we should be honest about whether we’re the right fit right now. We can do Salesforce write-back and Slack notifications, but a fully embedded experience as the primary UI—today—that’s not our strongest motion. I don’t want to oversell it.
Wendy Warren: I appreciate that. We’ve got another vendor in the mix that’s fully embedded. Their forecasting isn’t as deep, but adoption might be higher.

Camila Vega: That makes sense. Before you decide, can I sanity-check one thing: if we could prove, in a short pilot, that managers save time on weekly pipeline hygiene and your forecast variance shrinks—even with light rep involvement—would that be enough to justify starting manager-only?
Wendy Warren: Leadership might like it, but I don’t think I can get budget approval for something reps won’t adopt. Our CRO has been clear: no more “tools for managers.”

Camila Vega: Understood. Then the question becomes: is there a path where reps do adopt without full Salesforce embedding? For example, a rep gets a daily top-10 task list via email/Slack, and they execute inside Salesforce. They don’t need to live in our UI—just consume the prioritized list. Is that workable, or is it still a no?
Wendy Warren: It’s still risky for us. People ignore those lists after week one. And if they need to click out to understand “why,” they won’t. We’ve seen it too many times.
Camila Vega: Okay. Let’s not drag this out. Based on what you’re saying, the workflow friction—anything outside Salesforce—is a deal-breaker for this cycle. Is that accurate?
Wendy Warren: Yes. I think it is. I don’t want to waste your time or mine.

Camila Vega: I appreciate the clarity. One last option: we can pause the commercial process and revisit when we have deeper Salesforce embedding on our roadmap, or if your requirements change. Would you prefer we close the loop for now and reconnect in, say, two quarters?
Wendy Warren: That’s probably best. We’re making a decision in the next few weeks, and I don’t see this getting through procurement given the adoption concern.

Camila Vega: Completely fair. I’ll mark Quantacrest as “closed for now” rather than keep pushing. If you’re open to it, I can send a short recap of what Sales_Accelerator would have solved—forecast drivers, slippage diagnostics, and the pipeline hygiene automation—so you have it as a reference, and then we can check in later.
Wendy Warren: Yes, send that. And if you do get to a more Salesforce-native rep experience, I’d be willing to take another look.

Camila Vega: Will do. Thanks, Wendy. I appreciate how direct you were—better to make the right call than force a fit. I’ll follow up with that recap and a proposed time to reconnect later in the year.
Wendy Warren: Sounds good. Thanks, Camila.
